column2: pronounced [ˈkoɾkɪɟ]
column3: from corcach
column4: meaning "marsh") is the second largest city in Ireland
column5: located in the south-west of Ireland
column6: in the province of Munster. Following an extension to the city's boundary in 2019
column7: its population is c. 210
column8: 000.The city centre is an island positioned between two channels of the River Lee which meet downstream at the eastern end of the city centre
column9: where the quays and docks along the river lead outwards towards Lough Mahon and Cork Harbour
column10: one of the largest natural harbours in the world.Originally a monastic settlement
column11: Cork was expanded by Viking invaders around 915. Its charter was granted by Prince John in 1185. Cork city was once fully walled
column12: and the remnants of the old medieval town centre can be found around South and North Main streets. The third largest city by population on the island of Ireland
column13: the city's cognomen of "the rebel city" originates in its support for the Yorkist cause in the Wars of the Roses. Corkonians sometimes refer to the city as "the real capital"
column14: a reference to its opposition to the Anglo-Irish Treaty in the Irish Civil War.

column1: Cork was originally a monastic settlement
column2: reputedly founded by Saint Finbarr in the 6th century. Cork became (more) urbanised some point between 915 and 922 when Norseman (Viking) settlers founded a trading port. It has been proposed that
column3: like Dublin
column4: Cork was an important trading centre in the global Scandinavian trade network. The ecclesiastical settlement continued alongside the Viking longphort
column5: with the two developing a type of symbiotic relationship; the Norsemen providing otherwise unobtainable trade goods for the monastery
column6: and perhaps also military aid.

column1: The city's charter was granted by Prince John
column2: as Lord of Ireland
column3: in 1185. The city was once fully walled
column4: and some wall sections and gates remain today. For much of the Middle Ages
column5: Cork city was an outpost of Old English culture in the midst of a predominantly hostile Gaelic countryside and cut off from the English government in the Pale around Dublin. Neighbouring Gaelic and Hiberno-Norman lords extorted "Black Rent" from the citizens to keep them from attacking the city. The present extent of the city has exceeded the medieval boundaries of the Barony of Cork City; it now takes in much of the neighbouring Barony of Cork. Together
column6: these baronies are located between the Barony of Barrymore to the east
column7: Muskerry East to the west and Kerrycurrihy to the south.

column1: The city's municipal government was dominated by about 12–15 merchant families
column2: whose wealth came from overseas trade with continental Europe – in particular the export of wool and hides and the import of salt
column3: iron and wine.

column1: The medieval population of Cork was about 2
column2: 100 people. It suffered a severe blow in 1349 when almost half the townspeople died of plague when the Black Death arrived in the town. In 1491
column3: Cork played a part in the English Wars of the Roses when Perkin Warbeck
column4: a pretender to the English throne
column5: landed in the city and tried to recruit support for a plot to overthrow Henry VII of England. The then mayor of Cork and several important citizens went with Warbeck to England but when the rebellion collapsed they were all captured and executed.

column1: The title of Mayor of Cork was established by royal charter in 1318
column2: and the title was changed to Lord Mayor in 1900 following the knighthood of the incumbent mayor by Queen Victoria on her visit to the city.Since the nineteenth century
column3: Cork had been a strongly Irish nationalist city
column4: with widespread support for Irish Home Rule and the Irish Parliamentary Party
column5: but from 1910 stood firmly behind William O'Brien's dissident All-for-Ireland Party. O'Brien published a third local newspaper
column6: the Cork Free Press. Cork was overtaken by Belfast as Ireland's second largest city in the nineteenth-century.

column2: the centre of Cork was burnt down by the British Black and Tans
column3: in an event known as the "Burning of Cork" and saw fierce fighting between Irish guerrillas and UK forces. During the Irish Civil War
column4: Cork was for a time held by anti-Treaty forces
column5: until it was retaken by the pro-Treaty National Army in an attack from the sea.

column2: like the vast majority of Ireland
column3: is mild oceanic (Cfb in the Köppen climate classification) and changeable with abundant rainfall and a lack of temperature extremes. Cork lies in plant Hardiness zone 9b. Met Éireann maintains a climatological weather station at Cork Airport
column4: a few kilometres south of the city centre. The airport is at an altitude of 151 metres (495 ft) and temperatures can often differ by a few degrees between the airport and the rest of the city. There are also smaller synoptic weather stations at UCC and Clover Hill. Due to its position on the coast
column5: Cork city is subject to occasional flooding.Temperatures below 0 °C (32 °F) or above 25 °C (77 °F) are rare. Cork Airport records an average of 1
column6: 227.9 millimetres (48.34 in) of precipitation annually
column7: most of which is rain. The airport records an average of 7 days of hail and 11 days of snow or sleet a year; though it only records lying snow for 2 days of the year. The low altitude of the city
column8: and moderating influences of the harbour
column9: mean that lying snow very rarely occurs in the city itself. There are on average 204 "rainy" days a year (over 0.2 millimetres (0.0079 in) of rainfall)
column10: of which there are 73 days with "heavy rain" (over 5 millimetres (0.20 in)). Cork is also a generally foggy city
column11: with an average of 97 days of fog a year
column12: most common during mornings and during winter. Despite this
column14: Cork is also one of Ireland's sunniest cities
column15: with an average of 3.9 hours of sunshine every day and only having 67 days where there is no "recordable sunshine"

column1: The Cork School of Music and the Crawford College of Art and Design provide a throughput of new blood
column2: as do the active theatre components of several courses at University College Cork (UCC). Important elements in the cultural life of the city are: Corcadorca Theatre Company
column3: of which Cillian Murphy was a troupe member prior to Hollywood fame; the Institute for Choreography and Dance
column4: a national contemporary dance resource; the Triskel Arts Centre (capacity c.90)
column5: which includes the Triskel Christchurch independent cinema; dance venue the Firkin Crane (capacity c.240); the Cork Academy of Dramatic Art (CADA) and Graffiti Theatre Company; and the Cork Jazz Festival
column6: Cork Film Festival and Live at the Marquee events. The Everyman Palace Theatre (capacity c.650) and the Granary Theatre (capacity c.150) both host plays throughout the year.

column6: Dali

column1: The city's literary community centres on the Munster Literature Centre and the Triskel Arts Centre. The short story writers Frank O'Connor and Seán Ó Faoláin hailed from Cork
column2: and contemporary writers include Thomas McCarthy
column3: Gerry Murphy
column4: and novelist and poet William Wall.

column1: Additions to the arts infrastructure include modern additions to the Crawford Municipal Art Gallery and renovations to the Cork Opera House in the early 21st century. The Lewis Glucksman Gallery opened in the Autumn of 2004 at UCC
column2: was nominated for the Stirling Prize in the United Kingdom
column3: and the building of a new €60 million School of Music was completed in September 2007.

column1: Cork was the European Capital of Culture for 2005
column2: and in 2009 was included in the Lonely Planet's top 10 "Best in Travel 2010". The guide described Cork as being "at the top of its game: sophisticated
column3: vibrant and diverse".There is a rivalry between Cork and Dublin
column4: similar to the rivalry between Manchester and London
column5: Melbourne and Sydney or Barcelona and Madrid. Some Corkonians view themselves as different from the rest of Ireland
column6: and refer to themselves as "The Rebels"; the county is known as the Rebel County. This view sometimes manifests itself in humorous references to the Real Capital and the sale of T-shirts with light-hearted banners celebrating The People's Republic of Cork.

column1: The city has many local traditions in food
column2: including crubeens
column3: tripe and drisheen
column4: which were historically served in eating houses like that run by Katty Barry in the mid-20th century. The English Market sells locally produced foods
column5: including fresh fish
column6: meats
column7: fruit and vegetables
column8: eggs and artisan cheeses and breads. During certain city festivals
column9: food stalls are also sometimes erected on city streets such as St. Patrick's Street or Grand Parade.

column2: part of the Southwest dialect of Hiberno-English
column3: displays various features which set it apart from other accents in Ireland. Patterns of tone and intonation often rise and fall
column4: with the overall tone tending to be more high-pitched than other Irish accents. English spoken in Cork has a number of dialect words that are peculiar to the city and environs. Like standard Hiberno-English
column5: some of these words originate from the Irish language
column6: but others through other languages Cork's inhabitants encountered at home and abroad. The Cork accent displays varying degrees of rhoticity
column7: usually indicative of the speaker's local community.

column1: Broadcasting companies based in Cork include RTÉ Cork
column2: which has a radio
column3: television and production unit on Father Matthew Street in the city centre. Communicorp Media opened a radio studio in 2019 in the city covering content on both Today FM and Newstalk. Virgin Media Television also has an office in the city which covers local news stories developing within the city and county.The city's FM radio band features RTÉ Radio 1
column4: RTÉ 2fm
column5: RTÉ lyric fm
column6: RTÉ Raidió na Gaeltachta

column13: UCC 98.3FM (formerly Cork Campus Radio 97.4fm) and Christian radio station Life 93.1FM. Cork also has a temporary licensed citywide community station 'Cork FM Community Radio' on 100.5FM
column14: which is on-air on Saturdays and Sundays only. Cork has also been home to pirate radio stations
column15: including South Coast Radio and ERI in the 1980s. Today some small pirates stations remain.

column1: Cork is home to one of Ireland's main national newspapers
column2: the Irish Examiner (formerly the Cork Examiner). Its 'sister paper'
column3: The Echo (formerly the Evening Echo)
column4: was for decades connected to the "Echo boys"
column5: who were poor and often homeless children who sold the newspaper. Today
column6: the shouts of the vendors selling the Echo can still be heard in parts of the city centre. One of the biggest free newspapers in the city is the Cork Independent. The city's university publishes the UCC Express and Motley magazine.

column1: Cork features architecturally notable buildings originating from the Medieval to Modern periods. The only notable remnant of the Medieval era is the Red Abbey. There are two cathedrals in the city; St. Mary's Cathedral and Saint Fin Barre's Cathedral. St Mary's Cathedral
column2: often referred to as the North Cathedral
column3: is the Catholic cathedral of the city and was begun in 1808. Its distinctive tower was added in the 1860s. St Fin Barre's Cathedral serves the Church of Ireland (Anglican) and is possibly the more famous of the two. It is built on the foundations of an earlier cathedral. Work began in 1862 and ended in 1879 under the direction of architect William Burges.

column2: the main street of the city which was remodelled in the mid-2000s
column3: is known for the architecture of the buildings along its pedestrian-friendly route and is the main shopping thoroughfare. At its northern end is a landmark statue of Father Mathew. The reason for its curved shape is that it was originally a channel of the River Lee which was built over on arches. The General Post Office
column4: with its limestone façade
column5: is on Oliver Plunkett Street
column6: on the site of the Theatre Royal  which was built in 1760 and burned down in 1840. The English circus proprietor Pablo Fanque rebuilt an amphitheatre on the spot in 1850
column7: which was subsequently transformed into a theatre and then into the present General Post Office in 1877.

column1: The Grand Parade is a tree-lined avenue
column2: home to offices
column3: shops and financial institutions. The old financial centre is the South Mall
column4: with several banks whose interior derive from the 19th century
column5: such as the Allied Irish Bank's which was once an exchange.

column1: Many of the city's buildings are in the Georgian style
column2: although there are a number of examples of modern landmark structures
column3: such as County Hall tower
column4: which was
column5: at one time the tallest building in Ireland until being superseded by another Cork City building: The Elysian. Outside the County Hall is the landmark sculpture of two men
column6: known locally as 'Cha and Miah'. Across the river from County Hall is Ireland's longest building; built in Victorian times
column7: Our Lady's Psychiatric Hospital has now been partially renovated and converted into a residential housing complex called Atkins Hall
column8: after its architect William Atkins.Cork's most famous building is the church tower of Shandon
column9: which dominates the North side of the city. It is widely regarded as the symbol of the city. The North and East sides are faced in red sandstone
column10: and the West and South sides are clad in the predominant stone of the region
column11: white limestone. At the top sits a weather vane in the form of an eleven-foot salmon. Another site in Shandon is Skiddy's Almshouse
column12: which was built in the 18th century to provide a home to the poorest of the city.

column2: another notable building of limestone
column3: replaced the previous one which was destroyed by the Black and Tans during the War of Independence in an event known as the "Burning of Cork". The cost of this new building was provided by the UK Government in the 1930s as a gesture of reconciliation.

column1: Other notable places include Elizabeth Fort
column2: the Cork Opera House
column3: Christ Church on South Main Street (now the Triskel Arts Centre and original site of early Hiberno-Norse church)
column4: and St Mary's Dominican Church on Popes Quay. Other popular tourist attractions include the grounds of University College Cork
column5: through which the River Lee flows
column6: the Women's Gaol at Sunday's Well (now a heritage centre) and the English Market. This covered market traces its origins back to 1610
column7: and the present building dates from 1786.Parks and amenity spaces include Fitzgerald's Park to the west of the city (which contains the Cork Public Museum)
column8: the angling lake known as The Lough
column9: Bishop Lucey Park (which is centrally located and contains a portion of the old city wall) and the Marina and Atlantic Pond (an avenue and amenity near Blackrock used by joggers
column10: runners and rowing clubs).Up until April 2009
column11: there were also two large commercial breweries in the city. The Beamish and Crawford on South Main Street closed in April 2009 and transferred production to the Murphy's brewery in Lady's Well. This brewery also produces Heineken for the Irish market. There is also the Franciscan Well brewery
column12: which started as an independent brewery in 1998 but has since been acquired by Coors.

column3: Cork is the second-most populous city in the State and the 16th-most populous area of local government. Per the Local Government Act 2001
column4: Cork City Council is a tier-1 entity of local government with the same status in law as a county council.

column1: While local government in Ireland has limited powers in comparison with other countries
column2: the council has responsibility for planning
column3: roads
column4: sanitation
column5: libraries
column6: street lighting
column7: parks
column8: and a number of other important functions. Cork City Council has 31 elected members representing six electoral areas. As of the 2019 Cork City Council election
column9: the council's members are affiliated to the following political parties: Fianna Fáil (8 members)
column16: Independents (5 members). Certain councillors are co-opted to represent the city at the South-West Regional Authority. A new Lord Mayor of Cork is chosen in a vote by the elected members of the council under a D'Hondt system count. Since June 2020
column17: the mayor has been Joe Kavanagh of Fine Gael.Cork City Hall is located along Albert Quay on the south side of the city. It officially opened on 8 September 1936
column18: following the previous building being destroyed in the "Burning of Cork" in 1920. The administrative offices for Cork County Council are also located within the city limits
column19: on the Carrigrohane Road on the west side of the city.For the purposes of elections to Dáil Éireann
column20: the city is part of two constituencies: Cork North-Central and Cork South-Central which each returns four TDs. Following the 2016 general election
column21: these constituencies together returned two TDs for the Fine Gael party
column23: two for Sinn Féin and one for the Anti-Austerity Alliance-People Before Profit.

column2: cabinet approval was given for an extension of the Cork City Council boundary
column3: to include Cork Airport
column4: Douglas
column5: Ballincollig and other surrounding areas. This extension was completed in mid-2019.

column1: Cork City is a hub of industry in the region. Several pharmaceutical companies have invested heavily in the area
column2: including Pfizer Inc.
column3: Johnson & Johnson and Swiss company Novartis. Perhaps the most famous product of the Cork pharmaceutical industry is Viagra. Cork is also the European headquarters of Apple Inc. where over 3
column4: 000 staff are involved in manufacturing
column5: R&D and customer support. Logitech and EMC Corporation are also important IT employers in the area. Three hospitals are also among the top ten employers in the city.The city is also home to the Heineken Brewery that brews Murphy's Irish Stout and the nearby Beamish and Crawford brewery (taken over by Heineken in 2008) which have been in the city for generations. 45% of the world's Tic Tac sweets are manufactured at the city's Ferrero factory. For many years
column6: Cork was the home to Ford Motor Company
column7: which manufactured cars in the docklands area before the plant was closed in 1984. Henry Ford's grandfather was from West Cork
column8: which was one of the main reasons for opening up the manufacturing facility in Cork. Technology has since replaced the older manufacturing businesses of the 1970s and 1980s
column9: with people now working at a number of IT companies across the city area – such as Amazon.com
column11: which has offices at Cork Airport Business Park.Cork's deep harbour allows large ships to enter
column12: bringing trade and easy import/export of products. Cork Airport also allows easy access to continental Europe and Cork Kent railway station in the city centre provides good rail links for domestic trade.

column1: Cork Airport is the second busiest airport in the Republic of Ireland
column2: and is situated on the south side of Cork city close to Ballygarvan. Nine airlines fly to more than 45 destinations in Europe. Scheduled airlines using Cork airport include Aer Lingus
column3: Aer Lingus Regional operated by Stobart Air
column4: Air France
column5: Flybe
column6: Iberia Express
column7: Ryanair
column8: Swiss International Air Lines and Volotea.

column1: Public bus services within the city are provided by the national bus operator Bus Éireann. City routes are numbered from 201 through to 226 and connect the city centre to the principal suburbs
column2: colleges
column3: shopping centres and places of interest. Two of these bus routes provide orbital services across the Northern and Southern districts of the city respectively. Buses to the outer suburbs and towns
column4: such as Ballincollig
column5: Glanmire
column6: Midleton and Carrigaline are provided from the city's bus terminal at Parnell Place in the city centre. Suburban services also include shuttles to Cork Airport
column7: and a park and ride facility in the south suburbs only.

column1: Long-distance buses depart from the bus terminal in Parnell Place to destinations throughout Ireland. Hourly services run to Killarney/Tralee
column2: Waterford
column3: Athlone and Shannon Airport/Limerick/Galway and there are six services daily to Dublin. There is also a daily Eurolines bus service that connects Cork to Victoria Coach Station in London via South Wales and Bristol.

column2: Aircoach and Dublin Coach. Irish Citylink serves Limerick and Galway. Aircoach operates an Express non-stop service which serves Dublin City Centre and Dublin Airport 18 times daily in each direction. Dublin Coach serves Dublin via Fermoy
column3: Mitchelstown
column4: Cashel and Cahir.

column2: from Rushbrooke to Passage West
column3: links the R624 to R610. This service is used by some commuters to avoid traffic in the Jack Lynch Tunnel and Dunkettle area. The Port of Cork is situated at Ringaskiddy
column4: 16 kilometres (10 miles) SE via the N28. Brittany Ferries operates direct car ferry services from Cork to Roscoff in France.

column1: The city's road infrastructure improved in the late 20th and early 21st century
column2: including from the early 1980s construction of the Cork South Link dual carriageway which links the Kinsale Road roundabout with the city centre. Shortly after
column3: the first sections of the South Ring dual carriageway were opened. Work continued on extending the N25 South Ring Road through the 1990s
column4: culminating in the opening of the Jack Lynch Tunnel under the River Lee. The Kinsale Road flyover opened in August 2006 to remove a bottleneck for traffic heading to Cork Airport or Killarney. Other projects completed at this time include the N20 Blackpool bypass and the N20 Cork to Mallow road projects. The N22 Ballincollig dual carriageway bypass
column5: which links to the Western end of the Cork Southern Ring road was opened in September 2004. City centre road improvements include the Patrick Street project – which reconstructed the street with a pedestrian focus. The M8 motorway links Cork with Dublin.

column2: cycle paths and bike stands were added in a number of areas. Subsequently
column4: a public bicycle rental scheme was launched. The scheme is operated by An Rothar Nua on behalf of the National Transport Authority
column5: with funding supplemented by an advertising sponsor. The scheme supports 330 bikes with 31 stations placed around the city for paid public use.

column1: Cork was one of the most rail-oriented cities in Ireland
column2: featuring eight stations at various times. The main route
column3: still much the same today
column4: is from Dublin Heuston. Originally terminating on the city's outskirts at Blackpool
column5: the route now reaches the city centre terminus of Kent Station via the Glanmire tunnel and Kilnap Viaduct. Now a through station
column6: the line through Kent connects the towns of Cobh and Midleton east of the city. This also connected to the seaside town of Youghal
column7: until the 1980s.

column1: Other rail routes terminating or traversing Cork city were the Cork
column2: Blackrock and Passage Railway
column3: a line to Macroom
column4: the Cork and Muskerry Light Railway to Blarney
column5: Coachford and Donoughmore
column6: as well as the Cork
column7: Bandon and South Coast Railway connecting Bantry
column8: Skibbereen
column9: Clonakilty and many other West Cork towns. West Cork trains terminated at Albert Quay
column10: across the river from Kent Station (though an on-street rail system connected the two for rolling stock and cargo movement).

column1: Within the city there have been two tram networks in operation. A proposal to develop a horse-drawn tram (linking the city's railway termini) was made by American George Francis Train in the 1860s
column2: and implemented in 1872 by the Cork Tramway Company. However
column3: the company ceased trading in 1875 after Cork Corporation refused permission to extend the line.In December 1898
column4: the Cork Electric Tramways and Lighting Company began operating on the Blackpool–Douglas
column5: Summerhill–Sunday's Well and Tivoli–Blackrock routes. Increased usage of cars and buses in the 1920s led to a reduction in the use of trams
column6: which discontinued operations permanently on 30 September 1931.

column2: including the city's suburbs
column3: is served by three railway stations. These are Cork Kent railway station
column4: Little Island railway station and Glounthaune railway station.

column1: Cork's Kent Station is the main railway station in the city. From here
column2: Irish Rail services run to destinations all over Ireland. The main line from Cork to Dublin has hourly departures on the half-hour from Cork
column3: and is linked from Limerick Junction with connections to Clonmel and Waterford. InterCity services are also available to Killarney and Tralee
column4: and to Limerick
column5: Ennis
column6: Athenry and Galway (via Limerick Junction and the Limerick to Galway railway line).The Cork Suburban Rail system also departs from Kent Station and provides connections to parts of Metropolitan Cork. Stations include Little Island
column7: Mallow
column8: Midleton
column9: Fota and Cobh. In July 2009 the Glounthaune to Midleton line was reopened
column10: with new stations at Carrigtwohill and Midleton (and additional stations proposed for Blarney and elsewhere). Little Island railway station serves Cork's Eastern Suburbs.

column1: Cork is an important educational centre in Ireland – There are over 35
column2: 000 third level students in the city
column3: meaning the city has a higher ratio of students in the population than the national average. Over 10% of the population of the Metropolitan area are students in University College Cork (UCC) and Cork Institute of Technology (CIT)
column4: including nearly 3
column5: 000 international students from over 100 different countries. UCC is a constituent university of the National University of Ireland and offers courses in arts
column6: commerce
column7: engineering
column8: law
column9: medicine and science. It  has been named "Irish University of the Year" four times since 2003
column10: most recently in 2016. Cork Institute of Technology (CIT) was named Irish "Institute of Technology of the Year" in 2007
column11: 2010 and 2016 and offers third level courses in Computing and IT

column1: The National Maritime College of Ireland is located in Cork and is the only Irish college in which Nautical Studies and Marine Engineering can be undertaken. CIT incorporates the Cork School of Music and Crawford College of Art and Design as constituent schools. The Cork College of Commerce is the largest 'College of Further Education' in Ireland. Other 3rd level institutions include Griffith College Cork
column2: a private institution
column3: and various other colleges.

column1: Research institutes linked to the third level colleges in the city support the research and innovation capacity of the city and region. Examples include the Tyndall National Institute (ICT hardware research)
column2: IMERC (Marine Energy)
column3: Environmental Research Institute
column4: NIMBUS (Network Embedded Systems); and CREATE (Advanced Therapeutic Engineering). UCC and CIT also have start-up company incubation centres. In UCC
column5: the IGNITE Graduate Business Innovation Centre aims to foster and support entrepreneurship. In CIT
column6: The Rubicon Centre is a business innovation hub that is home to 57 knowledge based start-up companies.

column2: Gaelic football
column3: hurling and association football are popular sporting pastimes for Corkonians.

column1: Hurling and football are the most popular spectator sports in the city. Hurling has a strong identity with city and county – with Cork winning 30 All-Ireland Championships. Gaelic football is also popular
column2: and Cork has won 7 All-Ireland Senior Football Championship titles. Cork is the only county that has won both championships at least 7 times and the only that has won both in the 21st century. There are many Gaelic Athletic Association clubs in Cork City
column3: including Blackrock National Hurling Club
column4: St. Finbarr's
column5: Glen Rovers
column6: Na Piarsaigh
column7: Nemo Rangers and Douglas GAA. The main public venues are Páirc Uí Chaoimh and Páirc Uí Rinn (named after the noted Glen Rovers player Christy Ring). Camogie (hurling for ladies) and women's Gaelic football are increasing in popularity.

column1: Cork City F.C. are the largest and most successful association football team in Cork
column2: winning three League of Ireland titles
column3: four FAI Cup titles
column4: and one "All Ireland" Setanta Sports Cup title. They play their home games on the south side of the city in Turners Cross. Several
column5: now defunct
column6: Cork clubs played in the League of Ireland before 1984. In total
column7: teams from the city have won the league 12 times. Association football is also played by amateur and school clubs across the city
column8: as well as in "five-a-side" style leagues.

column1: Rugby union is played at various levels
column2: from school to senior league level. There are two first division clubs in Cork city. Cork Constitution (five-time All Ireland League Champions) play their home games in Ballintemple and Dolphin R.F.C. play at home in Musgrave Park. Other notable rugby clubs in the city include
column3: Highfield
column4: Sunday's Well and UCC. At schools level
column5: Christian Brothers College and Presentation Brothers College are two of the country's better known rugby nurseries.

column1: Munster Rugby plays a number of its home matches in the Pro14 at Musgrave Park in Ballyphehane. In the past Heineken Cup matches have also been played at Musgrave Park
column2: but most of these are now played at Thomond Park in Limerick. In May 2006 and again in May 2008 Munster became the Heineken Cup champions
column3: with many players hailing from Cork city and county.

column1: There are a variety of watersports in Cork
column2: including rowing and sailing. There are five rowing clubs training on the river Lee
column3: including Shandon BC
column4: UCC RC
column5: Pres RC
column6: Lee RC
column7: and Cork BC. Naomhóga Chorcaí is a rowing club whose members row traditional naomhóga on the Lee in occasional competitions. The "Ocean to City" race has been held annually since 2005
column8: and attracts teams and boats from local and visiting clubs who row the 24 kilometres (15 mi) from Crosshaven into Cork city centre. The National Rowing Center was moved to Inniscarra – approximately 12 km outside the city centre – in 2007. Cork's maritime sailing heritage is maintained through its sailing clubs. The Royal Cork Yacht Club located in Crosshaven (outside the city) is the world's oldest yacht club
column9: and "Cork Week" is a notable sailing event.

column1: The most notable cricket club in Cork is Cork County Cricket Club
column2: which was formed in 1874. Although located within the Munster jurisdiction
column3: the club plays in the Leinster Senior League. The club plays at the Mardyke
column4: a ground which has hosted three first-class matches in 1947
column5: 1961 and 1973. All three involved Ireland playing Scotland. The Cork Cricket Academy operates within the city
column6: with the stated aim of introducing the sport to schools in the city and county. Cork's other main cricket club
column7: Harlequins Cricket Club
column8: play close to Cork Airport. The provincial representative side
column9: the Munster Reds
column10: plays its home matches in the Twenty20 Inter-Provincial Trophy at the Mardyke Cricket Ground.

column1: The city contains clubs active in national competitions in basketball (Neptune and UCC Demons) and American Football (Cork Admirals). There are also golf
column2: pitch and putt
column3: hockey
column4: tennis
column5: and athletics clubs in the Cork area.

column1: The city is the home of road bowling
column2: which is played in the north-side and south-west suburbs. There are boxing and martial arts clubs (including Brazilian jiu-jitsu
column3: Karate
column4: Muay Thai and Taekwondo) within the city
column5: while the sports-based performance art of professional wrestling maintains a presence via local promotion Phoenix Wrestling. Cork Racing
column6: a motorsport team based in Cork
column7: has raced in the Irish Formula Ford Championship since 2005. Cork also hosts one of Ireland's most successful Australian Rules Football teams
column8: the Leeside Lions
column9: who have won the Australian Rules Football League of Ireland Premiership several times.

column1: Legislation to expand the boundary of the city
column2: which would increase its area to 187 km2 (72 sq mi) and the population within its bounds from 125
column5: was debated and approved in Dáil Éireann in June 2018. Corresponding legislation was drafted during July 2018
column6: and signed into law
